H0.text: Convergent evolution is the phenomenon that makes organisms, such as a porpoise and a shark, appear similar in outward appearances while actually not being closely related.

H1.text: Adaptive radiation is the process that explains why organisms, such as a porpoise and a shark, may appear similar in outward appearances yet are not closely related.

H2.text: Artificial selection is the cause of the similarity in outward appearances of organisms, such as a porpoise and a shark, which seem closely related but are not.

H3.text: Genetic equilibrium is the result of organisms that appear similar in outward appearances, such as a porpoise and a shark, yet are not closely related.

A4.text: Swimming animals including fish such as herrings, marine mammals such as dolphins, and ichthyosaurs (of the Mesozoic) all converged on the same streamlined shape.

A5.text: Echolocation has evolved separately in cetaceans (dolphins and whales) and bats, but from the same genetic mutations.
